newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks end up, lifted by laggards.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks end up, lifted by laggards.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks ended firmer on Wednesday as late buying of market laggards erased earlier losses, traders said.
The Hang Seng index closed 40.56 points higher at 11,379.49 after falling to a session low of 11,295.53. Turnover was HK$3.65 billion compared to HK$3.50 billion on Tuesday.

"Lately there has been a lot of attention on laggards and investment property stocks, and conglomerates have been the most important laggards up until now," said Glenn Lesko, head of sales trading at HG Asia.
Among them, Swire Pacific gained HK$1.00 to HK$69.75 and Wheelock added HK$0.20 to HK$16.15. Wharf Holdings rose HK$0.35 to HK$30.10 and Henderson Investment rose HK$0.05 to HK$8.60.
"We have seen some switching out of outperformers and rotational buying," said Alex Tang, head of research at Yamaichi International.
He said utility stocks had particularly benefited with the Hang Seng utilities sub-index closing on a gain of 99.33 points at 9,789.07.
"Earnings season is always the worst season for them. It's just one disappointment after another," said Lesko.
Guangshen Railway posted a 21.2 percent drop on interim net profit to 510.15 million yuan. The stock ended the session HK$0.05 lower at HK$3.00.

Shares of Hwa Kay Thai Holdings Ltd plunged to an all-time low after the company announced a rights issue plan and also reported a sharp fall in earnings. The stock closed HK$0.22 lower at HK$0.54 after hitting a low at HK$0.52.
